p: Drying out of samples under ambient conditions for two weeks resulted in an average reduction in fuel moisture contents of approximately 30% ( Fig. 2A), and the extent of this reduction did not differ significantly among vegetation groups ( H 2 = 1.4, p = 0.505). Dried samples exhibited increased flammability compared to their live counterparts, that is, an average increase in burn intensity of 115 °C; an 11% increase in completeness of burn; and a 46 seconds reduction in time-to-ignition ( Figs. 2B– 2D). However, this differential response in flammability between dried and live samples was comparable among the vegetation groups in terms of burn intensity ( H 2 = 0.8, p = 0.666), completeness of burn ( H 2 = 1.8, p = 0.410), and time-to-ignition ( H 2 = 0.6, p = 0.741).
